subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: One way to look at it is that in certain contexts, American speech can have a b sound which is understood to be a p . This is phonemic variation, a common
messageBody:
One way to look at it is that in certain contexts,
American speech can have a 'b' sound which is
understood to be a 'p'.
This is phonemic variation, a common attribute of
languages in which ordinary (not careful or formal)
speech confuses sounds in a context that is inherently
not confusing enough to matter -- to the speakers.

IPA is an overprecise way of specifying the exact
sound generated. Most American phonemes can take on
several different IPA sounds depending on context -
usually the preceding or sometimes following sound.

Look at it this way - after a short period of
assimilation, a Texan can understand a Brooklyn
speaker and a Californian Valley speaker - both of
which have widely varying pronunciations (and
intonations) of words.

Thus, a QS reader should be able to 'catch on' to
the phonemic variations in any ordinary dialect with
minimal confusion.

The major problem for the phonetic reader is that
pacing and intonation are not present in the written
word, and these can be clues to meaning. However, this
information is almost never a determining factor, thus
are not phonemic in English.

> But English speakers don't make the distinction
> between an aspirated and
> unaspirated P, so it doesn't really matter if the P
> is aspirated or not.
> If B is not voiced, it is a p, right?

===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein

American speech can have a 'b' sound which is
understood to be a 'p'.

languages in which ordinary (not careful or formal)
speech confuses sounds in a context that is inherently
not confusing enough to matter -- to the speakers.

sound generated. Most American phonemes can take on

   Look at it this way - after a short period of
assimilation, a Texan can understand a Brooklyn

which have widely varying pronunciations (and
intonations) of words.

   Thus, a QS reader should be able to 'catch on' to
the phonemic variations in any ordinary dialect with
